awd_titl_txt: RUI: Improving LIGO Optics and Data Quality to Increase the Rate and Accuracy of Gravitational-Wave Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
A century after the prediction of gravitational waves by Albert Einstein, the NSF-funded Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (Advanced LIGO) opened a new window on the Universe by discovering gravitational waves from merging binary systems of black holes and neutron stars. This award will extend the reach of Advanced LIGO, helping it to achieve its full promise. In particular, it will support research to reduce the amount of light that is "lost" when it hits the optics in gravitational-wave detectors and to apply Machine Learning techniques to find and remove disturbances in the detector data. This research will involve and provide transferable skills to a diverse team of undergraduate and Master's students at California State University Fullerton, a primarily undergraduate and Hispanic-serving institution. The results of this research will improve upon the state-of-the art in optics and deepen our understanding of the Universe through new gravitational-wave discoveries.     

This award renews support for California State University Fullerton's experimental gravitational-wave physics program. The PI will lead a team of undergraduate and master's students in research focused on two areas critical to extending the reach of Advanced LIGO. First, they will adapt techniques from Machine Learning to identify the physical processes that cause time-varying noise in the instruments and work to ameliorate them. This will increase the rate of gravitational-wave observations and the accuracy of the information extracted from them. Second, they will conduct experiments to identify the mechanisms behind light scattering in gravitational-wave detector optics, a key to the quantum noise that directly limits LIGO's sensitivity. A new instrument will be developed to test whether the long mysterious point-like scatter from LIGO optics is related to micro-crystals formed during annealing of the optics. This work will lead to higher quality optics and improve quantum-noise reduction techniques such as squeezed light in future gravitational-wave observatories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Albert Einstein predicted gravitational waves as a consequence of his general relativity theory in 1916. A century later, the NSF-funded Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) observed these waves from the black hole merger GW150914, opening a new spectrum for observing the Universe. Two years later, gravitational-wave multi-messenger astronomy debuted dramatically with LIGO and Europe's Virgo observatory discovering GW170817, a binary neutron star merger that was also observed across the electromagnetic spectrum. LIGO's astrophysical reach is limited by noise from the instruments and their environment. Improvements in the noise at LIGO and Virgo -- the product of intense work by the detector teams but also investigations supported by this grant and others -- have led to an increased rate of observations, with nearly 100 total systems now observed. 

Transient and non-stationary noise in the detector data can mimic or mask signals. Reducing the amplitude and rate of such noise is critical to identifying gravitational waves, enabling accurate astronomical alerts, and making precise statements about the source systems. Quantum noise of the laser light sets a broadband sensitivity limit. This noise is exacerbated by light scattered from LIGO's optics, which decreases the circulating laser power and limits the effectiveness of optical squeezing, the most powerful new technology to increase LIGO's quantum-noise-limited sensitivity. This award supported student-faculty research to improve LIGO's astrophysical reach by characterizing and helping to remove sources of transient and non-stationary noise in the instruments and through laboratory experiments to identify the mechanisms behind scattering in LIGO optics and to develop techniques to reduce the level of scattering.

This award led to the development of a new instrument to observe the optical scatter of coated optics and eventual damage mechanisms in-situ and in real-time during annealing. Experiments using this apparatus and angle-resolved scatterometers showed that post-deposition high-temperature annealing of amorphous thin-film coatings, such as those used by LIGO-Virgo, can lead to a decrease in optical scatter (alongside decreased absorption and mechanical loss measured by other groups). However, they also showed that if such coatings are annealed to high enough temperatures, they exhibit damage such as crystallization, cracking, blistering, or delamination. The award led to research identifying correlations between LIGO's astronomical range and auxiliary sensors using lasso regression. The resulting algorithm was run online daily on LIGO data to answer the question, "which of the many auxiliary sensors measure fluctuations similarly to LIGO's astrophysical range?". This award also led to information about the quality of LIGO data that was used to vet gravitational wave signal candidates for inclusion in the second transient gravitational-wave catalog, GWTC-2.

This project involved undergraduate and masters students from California State University Fullerton, a primarily undergraduate and Hispanic-serving and Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander-serving institution, in gravitational-wave research, education, and outreach. Through these projects these participants have taken part in the international efforts to observe gravitational waves with LIGO, Virgo, and Kagra and have developed skills in areas such as optics, machine learning, noise analysis, and computing that will be transferable to the STEM workforce.
